text: General man page layout contains:
NAME - name of a program with short description
SYNOPSIS - formal usage description
DESCRIPTION - text program description
EXAMPLES - examples of common usage
SEE ALSO - related programs
And many other such as:
CONFIGURATION, FILES, OPTION, EXIT STATUS, ERRORS, VERSIONS, NOTES, BUGS, AUTHORS
Sometimes there are a few different manual pages for one program. Such pages are divided into sections (Linux distribution order):
1 - General commands
2 - System calls
3 - C Library functions
4 - Special files
5 - File formats
6 - Games and screensavers
7 - Miscellanea
8 - System administration commands and daemons

text: What do 0, 1 and 2 have to do with this?
We can use 0, 1 and 2 to specifically tell which standard stream we want to redirect
Let's say we don't want to be bothered by errors - ls % 2>/dev/null
Or log them! - ls % >> logfile.txt
Or we want to log standard output and standard error - ls abc &> logfile.txt
As you can see redirecting output is much more interesting here :).
What is standard output?
In linux environment we have three preconnected input and output connection channels.
Namely:
- Standard input (stdin) represented by 0 (yes, zero)
- Standard output (stdout) represented by 1
- Standard error (stderr) - 2.
Under the hood 0, 1 and 2 are just handles to abstraction of a file - they say everthing in linux is a file.
What if we wanted to output to a file not to stdout?
cat, simple program used to print files to standard output
Most commontly switches are:
-n - shows line numbers
-E - shows line endings by $ sign
Redirection
To change data input or data output use:
- '>' Overwrites destination content with standard output
cat file.txt > file2.txt - prints file.txt to file2.txt
- '<' Overwrites standard input with given input
cat < file.txt - in fact works like cat file.txt
- '>>' Appends destination content with standard output
cat file.txt >> file2.txt - appends file.txt at the end of file2.txt
- '<<' Appends standard input with given input
If you use this one in real life please e-mail me

Program.main: cat - concatenate files and print on the standard output. Program initially meant for file concatenation, but serves as just one file printer just as good!

text: By the way, don't confuse root directory with root user these are two unrelated things
What is directory
Directories is an abstraction for organizing your data files in groups.
Linux filesystem is a hierarchical directory structure, which means directories form a tree graph.
Root of linux filesystem is /
Then we can have a folder and a file in it like: /etc/passwd
There can be a whole partition hidden under a directory!
So, let's imagine we are working in file directory /home/cezary/random/stuff/here/cool/working/directory
Imagine typing ls and that directory everytime. Remeber that ls without directory lists current working directory!
A lot of programs use that current working directory property. All in all 'cd' is here to make our linux-lives a lot comfier.
cd without argument usually(it can be changed) lands in your home directory.
How to specify directory?
There are two options:
Absolute path:
cd /opt/testing/data/ - starts with root directory / followed by subdirectories
Relative path:
cd home/cezary/notes - with current directory /user/backup/ path translates to /user/backup/home/cezary/notes
Probably you notices while typing ls -l two directories . and .., these are special directories indicating:
.. parent directory - cd ../../ while being at /home/cezary would land you at /
. current directory.

Program.main: cd - Change currently working Directory

Usage.cd: changes current directory to one specified by $HOME (usually /home/<username>)
Usage.cd ~username: changes directory to user's home directory

text: I am not covering all of regex here, it's pretty massive.
For now we need to know that there are some special characters that are helpful such as:
^ - begginging of like
$ - end of line
[a-z0-9] - one character that is a small letter or a number
. - any character
+ - pattern occuring one or more
* - pattern occuring zero or infinity times
? - pattern occuring once or
So, what do we have for now. Travesing through filesystem, and displaying stuff.
Log files tend to be long, what if we wanted filter input?
grep is a handy tool to achieve filtering
Mechanism is simple, we're giving input, pattern to match and some switches and get filtered output.
Pattern is specified by regex.
Handy switches:
-e <regex> - specifies explicitly that following string is a pattern, is not necessary but handy and makes starting your regex from '-' possible
-v - shows all lines NOT matching
-i - ignores the case of letters
-n - prints line number with the line

Program.main: grep - prints lines matching the pattern

Usage.grep -e \"a$\" log.txt: Searches log.txt for lines ending with letter a.
Usage.grep -ne \"missing\" log.txt: Searches log.txt for lines containing word 'missing', prints their line numbers.
Usage.grep IOException log.txt: Searches log.txt for lines containing IOException.
Usage.ls -l | grep -e \"^log.*24-08-2016.*txt$: Lists all files from current directory that are logs from 24.08.2016. '|' is here to get you curious :)
Usage.grep -ie \"missing\" log.txt: Searches log.txt for lines containing word 'missing' ignoring word case.

text: Why don't we print some middle section of a file
Here you go - head -200 log.txt | tail-10
How does it work?
Sometimes there's only a need for few lines at the beggining or end of file.
No problem, usage is pretty straightforward, please see Usage
Pipes
Operation we've done is possible because of invention of pipes denoted by |
It works by simply redirecting standard output (1) to standard input of another program (0)
Previous example works as follow
head cuts first 200 lines, then output is redirected to tail which cuts last 10 lines.
It is very powerfull tool, as you'll notice in following steps.

Program.main: head, tail - prints N first/last lines from file

text: Very robust utility meant to find files and directiories
Some of the popular switches (Please see man for full documentation):
+n -n n - respectively files bigger than, less than or equal to n for numerical values
-size n[c|w|b|k|M|G] - files size check, with unit k, M and G stand for kilo, mega and giga bytes
-executable - searches for files with execute permission
-user <uname> - searches for files owned by user <uname>
-name <filename> - searches for files with <filename> name
-exec <command> {} \; - executes given command, files found are denoted by {}.
-delete - deletes all findings

Program.main: find - prints N first/last lines from file

Usage.find / -name \"*.txt\": finds all .txt files in all directories
Usage.find -type d: finds all directories in our current directory
Usage.find -ctime -2: finds files with any changes performed less than two days ago
Usage.find -name \"*.java\" -exec cp {} /home/: finds all java files in current directory and copies them to given directory

text: Environment variables
These are a set of named values that affect behaviour of running processes
While executing any command in bash, it looks up for corresponding program in PATH variable
PWD - holds our current working directory
HOME - holds your home directory path
There are many more, to see all of your environment variables type 'printenv' in terminal
You can add your own variables as well as change already existing, however change might not be persistant
To change variable use 'export' <key>=<value>, where key is variable name and value is it's value.
If given key has more values than one, each value is separated by ':', see PATH.
To print given variable use echo $<key> pr printenv <key>
Program is used to find where given program is.
for instance which chromium would output us absolute path to this executable.
which works by looking up directories listed in PATH environmental variable.

Program.main: which - shows path of a executable program

Usage.printenv PATH: does the same as echo version
Usage.printenv \"MY OWN VARIABLE\": shows variable named MY OWN VARIABLE, note quotes

text: There are a lot of helpful text processors namely:
tr - translates or deletes character, used to transform text
sort - sorts lines of output
uniq - reports or omits repeated lines
cut - remove or extract given sections in lines
wc - word count
Whats best is that, they can be piped one to another!
Please see manual for more information

Usage.cat log.txt | tr \"[a-zA-Z]\" \"[n-za-mN: prints log.txt encrypted using ROT13 cipher
Usage../info.sh | tr -s \" \": transforms output of bashscript, by deleting trailing spaces
Usage.cat /etc/passwd | cut -d\":\" -f1,3: shows first and third column of paswd file with ':' as delimeter
Usage.cat log.txt | tr \"\\n\" \" \": Prints log.txt with newlines changed to spaces

text: For more throughout linux manual see Linux Fundamentals by Paul Cobbaut http://linux-training.be/linuxfun.pdf
This is it. You've finished BasicLinux maze.
More utilities to investigate, which are hard to make meaningful excercises in context of a maze:
mkdir, rmdir - creates/removes directory
touch - creates a file
mv, cp, rm - moves, copies, removes files/directories

There are two basic types of ciphers transpositions and substitutions. Transposition ciphers rearrange bits or characters in the data. Basically permutes(often periodically) words by given function - we then can permute these blocks etc. it can get really crazy ;).

Rule is to not give away any information easily. This is why we change all letters to uppercase - obfuscates where the word starts. Delete whitespaces and punctuation marks, to hide any extra information. Sometimes they add spaces every K characters so it obscure information even more. This isn't the case for modern day ciphers thanks to XOR operation and some math proof, we'll cover that later.

4.header: Weak points of the cipher are:
list: Close to proper keys can reveal large chunks of plain text correctly
Can be broken with simple annagramming
Oftenly security is based on the algorithm
Vunerable to bogo sort ;)

2.header: Security by obscurity or security by design?
text: One might think that security by not revealing the algorithm by inventing his own secret way is a good idea.

However, it is dated back to 1851 that smart security people came with conclusion that it is wrong. Why? People cracking ciphers already know more than what we could suprise them with. Also there is large spectrum of easy traps to fall into when creating an algorithm, that it is most probable that we'll fall into one.
Recently all algorithms prior to being called standard, are undergoing thorough verifications that can be done by anyone and is actually done by lots of Universities.
All in all, general idea is so algorithm is commonly known. Design is that so crypto security is based on secret key, not algorithm itself.
Although obscurity can help sometimes - it is advisable not to provide your credentials to anyone on the web ;)
Used in action by Germans during WWI. Idea is to draw an NxN grid and punch quater of holes and number them, then write letters through holes, then rotate grid 90 degrees and repeat.

Straighforward cipher, take a keyword and assign numbers to characters in alphabetical order (repeating letters from left to right). Fill each row with as much letters of plaintext as keyword length, then read columns in priorly created order. There can be fixed amount of rows each block. Encoding REALLYSECRETLOREMIPSMDOLOTROLOLO with keyword PIZZATIME

list: Check letter frequency and compare to general language letter frequency. Simple as that :)

Program.main: Transposition Ciphers - simply mixing letters

text: Every presented cipher, shows different vulnerabilities. For vignere cipher it is repeating key, take a look how many times A is shifted using F - a lot. This is how you decipher vignere, find repeating pattern like for instance FH in previous example, check the distance - it is 6 so key length is either six or any divider of six etc. The longer text is the easier it gets. That gives a conclusion we should use each key only once(so with FOX we could encrypt only 3 letters). Perfect secrecy is achieved when key is random, as long as the plain text, and can be used only once! Such cipher is called One Time Pad. Interestingly WEP wi-fi password could be easily broken due to using keys repeatingly with small key space. There is a way to achieve condition indistincable to perfect secrecy with smaller keys when probability - this will be cover in next step.

In this kind of ciphers, we do not change letter position, but their representation. For instance we could agree that square represents A, circle B and co forth. In another case every letter in alphabet could be represented by next one etc. In modern days ciphering algorithms change bits.

list: Pair plaintext letters into digrams. Crypto maniac -> CR YP TO MA NI AC
If both letters in digram are the same add filling letter - Q, or X or any agreed filling letter (it is common to use not frequently occuring letters)
If digram appears on the same row on lookup table use letters to their immidiate right.
If digram appears on the same column use letters immediately  below.
In other case use letters in the same row as letters from digram, but on other corners of rectangle created by given pair.
Order is important (not very important, but you don't want to figure each digram letter position. First letter is the letter that lies on the row same with the first letter of digram.
text: Proposed cipher, to then used Vigenere. In this cipher we are using 5x5 grid with letters (that either had to be remembered, or first used keyword followed by noral alphabet) and following principles (described in list below). Hey hey hey, 5x5 is 25 and there are 26 letters in the alphabet what is going on? Well one letter is either ommited (Q or X or J) or in some versions I and J are treated as same. Compared to vigenere this cipher is less vulnerable to frequency analysis as digrams possibilities equal to 676. The algorithm itself is not as easy to use though.

text: Idea is to shift shifted alphabet using a key. Mainly to distort letter frequency. We take the key indicating how much each corresponding letter should be shifted and repeat it throughout the message. It is using different rot cipher of corresponding number. With key FOX first letter would be shifted with rot6 (as F is sixth letter of alphabet), second by rot15, then X by rot24 and repeated.

text: We've got 26 letters in english alphabet - ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ
Rot cipher is denoted with function E(x) = (x + n) mod 26 for encryption and E(x) = (x - n) mod 26 for decryption.
Caesar cipher is special case of rot, where n is equal to 3. Shifted alphabet looks like this - DEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZABC

In general we could shift alphabet using f(x) = x<sup>t</sup>k<sub>t</sub> + x<sup>t</sup>k<sub>t-1</sub> ... xk<sub>1</sub> + k<sub>0</sub> mod n. n and k are relatively prime (there is some modulo math involved, please investigate). Affine transformation is linear polynomial of presented function.

3.header: Main substitution weakness - key letter frequency
text: With ROT cipher we could obviously try 26 shifted alphabets. Rest ciphers presented in this section broaden search space up to a point where pencil and paper brute force attack is not possible. There is, however, an attack using language key letter frequency. Simply extract repeating single, double and tripple letter strings and compare them to given language frequencies it should expose a lot about the plaintext and the key. There are many more frequencies that we could check, as for instance - first letter frequency
For more information about actual letter frequencies see wikipedia 'Letter Frequencies' article

The most secure paper-pencil cipher using technique called seration. Letters are encoded with base 3 numbers (using three chosen signs, normally 0 1 2). Each number is written under corresponding letter vertically, then read horizontally and encrypt into letters again (using previous encoding or new). We are using one character additionally as we can encode 27 letters and we have 26.

Program.main: Substitution Ciphers - simply changing letters

text: Strength of cipher is measured by computational complexity (time T and space S) algorithms used to break the cipher. It is characterized by f(n) where n is size of input. Characterization is done with big O notation that describes the limiting behavior of a function with values tends towards infinity. For example polynomial T = f(n) = n<sup>2</sup> + n + 5 equals O(n<sup>2</sup>). For such algorithm doubling input quadruples execution time.

What properties should such a generator have to be considered secure and in the same time be usable. Repeatability is achieved by using seeds - given say 58 bits we generate key that is exactly the same on two machines. However this poses a threat of our key to be easily computed by eavesdropper. This is the game we play, we have to create such key generating system that no adversary is able (not knowing the seed) guess our next computed bit. Specifically we consider generator to be secure only if any adversary given first k bits can guess half of k+1 bits for any polynomial algorithm.

list: P - polynomial, algorithms solvable in at most polynomial time
NP - nondeterministic polynomial, algorithms with no deterministic polynomial solution
text: NP algorithms are great for cryptography, some of them can be adapted so it is easy to compute one way and hard to compute where did the result come from.

We claimed that perfect secrecy can be achieved when key is as long as the message and used only once. One time key usage is pretty simple, however how to have keys not as long and still hold the principle?

Even if our key is uniformly distributed stream of bits, our plaintext surely is not. What operation should we use in order to combine the key and plaintext to get uniformly distributed ciphertext? For all possible bit operations 0, a & b, a > b, a, a < b, b, a % b, a | b, !a & !b, a == b, !b, a >= b, !a, a <= b, !a | !b, 1 (thanks stackoverflow) only these provide equal distribution of zeros and ones a, b, !a, !b, a % b, a == b. Xor(and xor negation) is the only suitable as it combines entropy of both ciphertext and plaintext. All in all modern cryptography is more or less xoring bits all and over again.

Program.main: How to achieve security within bit world?

text: In 2001 announced as standard by NIST created by two Belgian cryptographers. Among security main criteria was low RAM usage and high speed. Chosen algorithm is subset of Rijndael cipher - which is a family of ciphers with different key and block sizes (32 multiplication between 128 and 256 bits). AES was adapted in three versions 128, 192 and 256 bits of key with fixed plaintext block of 128 bits. Additionally AES alike DES is symmetric cipher - which means same key is used for encryption and decryption. Best known attacks reduce keyspace from 128, 192 and 256 bits of key to (about) respectively 126, 190 and 254 bits (which would as well take millions of years) additionally memory space needed to launch such attack is larger than size of every possible storage on earth. In summary there are no practical publicly known algorithms to break AES as of 2016.

Program.main: AES - Advanced Encryption Standard. Currently most widely used cipher in the world.

text: There can be other ciphers using NP class problems, not only modulo ones!

There is pair of keys, public (visible publicly to anyone interested) and private (kept hidden at all times). While encrypting with public key, only private key owner can decrypt it. When encrypting with private key, everyone can decrypt it but message sender is known. Let's then imagine insecure channel and a message which we first encrypt with our private key(to prove it is us), then encrypt with recipient public key. We send it, then recipent decodes with his private key and our public key. But how to implement such system ? And in the end why not just use this instead of symmetric ciphers at all - symmetric ciphers are much faster than asymmetric ones, therefor these are just used for establishing symmetric key.

list: Chose two primes p and q. Both should be similar in magnitude but should differ in length by few digits. p and q should also contain large prime factors, to make factoring hard
Compute n = pq - n is public modulus.
Compute Euler's totient function φ(n) - This number is private.
Select e that is lower and relatively prime to φ(n)
Compute inverse of e such that d*e = 1 (mod φ(n)), d = e<sup>-1</sup>. e is public key, d is private key.
text: Scheme was first published by Ron Rivest, Adi Shamir, and Leonard Adleman in 1977, it was however invented by Clifford Cocks used by UK inteligence and classified up untill 1997. RSA is commonly used, even today, in various digital world i.e. establishing VPN connection. Scheme goes as follows:

With symmetric ciphers both parties must obtain a key in order to start communicating securely. It can be done by meeting in person or by a courier - very risky methods. It could be done by sending next key using currently set secure route(it was done in enigma, remember setting indicator groups), this might be good idea but with intensity such connections are created and destroyed everyday setting initial route (situation where we have no secure route) is a problem to solve. This is where NP problems come in hand.

3.header: Deffie and Hellman public key distribution
list: Agree anyhow to use some q which is a prime number (the larger the better) and α < q
Alice and Bob choose random number - respectively M<sub>a</sub>, M</sub>b</sub> < q
Alice and Bob compute then C<sub>a</sub> = α<sup>M<sub>a</sub></sup> (mod q) and C<sub>b</sub> = α<sup>M<sub>b</sub></sup> (mod q) - this are public keys.

To obtain key Alice computes K<sub>a,b</sub> = C<sub>b</sub><sup>M<sub>a</sub></sup> (mod q), while Bob K<sub>a,b</sub> = C<sub>a</sub><sup>M<sub>b</sub></sup> (mod q). K<sub>a,b</sub> is used two times not by mistake, this is the same number.
text: It is perfect usage of NP problems. Given q is a prime number and integer α < q, C = α<sup>M</sup> (mod q) is easy to compute (check out quick modulo exponentiation algorithm), M = log<sub>α</sub>C (mod q) is hard - information over what M was based on C is lost because is might just as well be any other congruent number (like 1,5,9,13... is congruent modulo 4). Deffie Hellman scheme is commonly used in SSL cipher and goes as follows:

4.header: Famous Java String Hash Implementaion Error
text: Every Java object is provided with hash function - used for calculating bucket to store in a hashtable. There are many urban legends about the error. Going to Java 1.1.1 documentation, the implementation took at most 8 characters out of given String that were larger than 16 characters (This was done to improve performance). Diminishing input resulted in many collisions which in return resulted in poor hashtable performance. From Java 1.2 String hashcode is computed based on all String characters.

Digest functions, have really hard mathematical problem to face - birthday paradox. Problem is described as 'how many people do we have to check until we have 50% change that we find ANY two such that their birthday is on the same day' - whats the deal? The deal is that the number is only 23(probability = 50%), for p equal to 99,99% we need to ask 82 people. Amount of messages such that any two messages (chosen at random) turn out as the same hash is around square root of K possible hash outputs. This is the main reason that secure hashes are really long - starting from 224 bits (SHA-3) and up - but this is frequently changed to higher number. That was the first problem, the other is that hash has to appear completly random(discussed in Modern Day Ciphers).

list: Append Padding Bits - message is padded is congurent to 448 mod 512. Meaning message is 64 bits shy to being dividable by 512. Padding is always done, even if initial message is congruent to 448 mod 512 (for example length 0). To pad add SINGLE bit '1' followed then by adequate amount of zeroes.

Append length - 64 bit representation of message length (before padding) mod 2<sup>64</sup> is appended at the end of the message. This is done using two 32-bit words in little endian order. Let's call padded message M.

Initialize MD Buffer - set initial values to output state. Output is represented by four 32bit blocks denoted A, B, C and D. These are respectively filled up with 01234567, 89abcdef, fedcba98, 76543210 initial state - values in hex, little endian.
Process Message in 16-Word Blocks - just visit documentation
text: One of the most popular hash, nowadays regarded insecure for cryptography usage. It could still for example be used as hasher for strings or files(message integrity).

list: It is quick to compute - given any k bits it is fast to compute output.
It is hard to compute message for given hash - the only way is to try all possible messages(brute force)
Avalange effect - small change in input has to result in huge change in output
Collisions are hard to find - it is infeasible to find two messages that digest into same hash.
text: Hash functions has a lot of applications, as well as in cryptography as outside of it. Such function is mapping our k bits of input to arbitrary(often fixed) n bit output. There are few rules that need to be faces in order for hash function to be considered secure, though unsecure functions are also used for instance data integrity check. Ideal hash has following properties:

list: Hash tables - O(1) access data structures
Data integrity verification - we can check downloaded file whether it contains any errors
File identifier
Pseudorandom key derivation
Finding duplicate records
Password storage
text: You might have heard about MD5 cipher which outputs 126 bit hash. Now we can tell that this cipher is unsecure as we need only 2<sup>64</sup> tryouts to be very likely to hit collision (For current best supercomputer that would take about 3 seconds) . Imagine logging in with completly different password hashing into ours. Why is MD5 still so popular? Hashes have various of applications, not only concerning security. MD5 is relatively fast and collision-resistant-enough therefor perfect for some usage. Where are such functions used?

Program.main: Hash functions - workhorses of modern cryptography.

text: Problems we were facing so far - algorithm complexity vs security. Firsly we had to guarantee frequency analysis safety then Vigenere's cipher weakness was that we had to remember very long keys. Rotor machines were widespreadly in use starting from 1920 up to 1970. How does it work? Let's imagine substitution machine in which we input one letter and get substitued one as output according to some simple substitution formula. Let's then shift alphabet by one place after each press. Lets then connect that machine to another such machine and set it to shift with different interval. This is mechanically achieved by rotors. One rotor provides 26 alphabets, two - 26x26. Basically k rotors provide 26<sup>k</sup> alphabets while we have to remember k rotor starting positions.

list: Wheel order: V II IV
Alphabet position (ring order): 12, 5, 19
Plugboard connections: EO JY IV AX DU FQ PT MS WL CB
Reflector connection: EU DS LA GV OT ZF IX CH MR UK BP QW
text: Enigma worked using mentioned rotor machine, with each device few numbered (I II III IV V etc.) rotors were provided. Additionally rotors had reflector, it's a device connecting last rotor to itself. Such element provided that initial letter could not be translated into itself - which was great design flaw as it exposes information about the cipher. To add more security, presskeys had changeable wiring connections redirecting input and output. For E and G connected if E was pressed the signal was diverted to G, if G was output it was changed to E. All in all key consisted of wheel orders, wheel starting position, reflection setting, keyboard redirection setting(plugboard connection). They might use indicator groups which were chosen by sender and encoded by settings in book which had codes for given day, then rest of the message was encoded using indicator group starting position (ring order). See wikipedia for great and thorough explaination.

text: Input - 64 bit - is transposed using lookup table (IP), after encryption process it is transposed back using another lookup table (IP<sup>-1</sup>). In between lies heart of DES - Feistel Network. Plaintext is divided into two pieces(L and R). We apply encrypting function (f<sub>i</sub>) - using key k<sub>i</sub> - to right piece and XOR (⊕) it with left - this is right piece of next iteration, left one is right(without function applied) from previous iteration. This is easily understood after seeing graph.
Please come back to this chapter after getting idea of how DES works

DES has few major issues, like S-boxes may have hidden trapdoors. 58 bit key is very short for modern day and there is set of weak and semiweak keys that should be avoided (thus cipher key is not entirely random). Weak key is such that derivation of it produces 16 exactly same keys. There are four weak keys - 01 01 01 01 01 01 01 01, 1F 1F 1F 1F 1F 1F 1F 1F, E0 E0 E0 E0 E0 E0 E0 E0, FE FE FE FE FE FE FE FE. Semi weak key is such that key will derive to two keys (each occurring 8 time), there are 6 semiweak key pairs that will derive into exactly same 16 keys thus resulting in same ciphertext. These are major flaws of DES. Good things is that small change in plaintext results in huge change in ciphertext, as well as one bit of ciphertext depend on many bits of plaintext, des was considered pretty strong - it is computational power of circuits that made itgo to rest.

text: Application of function follows as - 32 bits are expanded into 48 using lookup table (E), then it is XOR'ed with given iteration key. Next these 48 bits are divided into 8 6-bit chunks each chunk is translated into 4 bits using corresponding S-box then concatenated resulting in 32 bit output. Note that s-box tables might not fit in your screen (scroll at the bottom, sorry)

Data encryption standard, based on LUCIFER cipher created at IBM in 1970 which after some changes was announced NBS (now NIST) standard which it was up to 2001, now replaced by AES. Currently dedicated machines are able to break DES cipher within one day. Des is symmetric cipher meaning it uses same key for encryption as for decryption. Des uses 64 bit key (of which 8 are pairity bits so it's 56 bit key) for enciphering blocks of 64 bit by applying set of substitution and transposition operations. All presented permutation tables are read from left to right, top bottom 58 on first position means that 58th bit goes on the 1st position.

Key is 58 bit plus additional 8 pairity bits which are expanded into 16 keys which are applied in enciphering process. Generation process starts by applying transposition (PC-1) table to key, then it is splitted into two 28 bit chunks (C and D). Subsequently each block is bitwise shifted left one or two bits at a time depending on a lookup table (LS). After each shift two blocks are merged by another transposition matrix(PC-2) producing a key - then another shift is made on the block up to 16 keys produced.
